-56-
SECTION FIVE
TOWARD A NATIONAL SYSTEMS CAPABILITY
We have been describing the necessity for re¬
lating to mass communications in order to meet
the increasing demands being made upon the local
Community Action Agency by the poverty population.
We have said that those demands will intensify
as we reach out to more and more of that popu¬
lation in the months ahead.
We have said that we are facing critical man¬
power shortages, at every level, as existing
staff take on wider responsibilities.
It is axiomatic, that where communication is weak,
it is impossible to develop effective community
action programs, and it is almost impossible to
involve people.
When there is little, or no communication, program
structures tend to become arbitrary, and reflect
some professional's view of "what the poor need."
Such programs are inadequate because they represent
an "idealized conception" of how to combat poverty
through so-called "proven" programming "method."
